fields.headline: Justin Trudeau: the right face with the wrong mouth for Canada's liberals?
fields.standfirst: The charismatic son of former PM wants to lead the Liberals back to power in Canada. But he'll have to watch his gaffes
fields.trailText: Colin Horgan: The charismatic son of former PM wants to lead the Liberals back to power in Canada. But he'll have to watch his gaffes
fields.body:
There is one recent instance that parliamentary reporters in Ottawa will recount when prompted with a question about how good Justin Trudeau might be at leading the Liberal party, and it's not a good one. Trudeau, who is 40 and the son of the former Canadian prime minister Pierre Trudeau, formally announced his intention to run for the Liberal party leadership on Tuesday evening at a rally in his home Montreal riding. His bid for leadership of the faltering Liberals was the worst-kept secret in Canadian politics, because everyone was eventually in on the whispering, and ran to tell the world about it. But now we know for sure what Trudeau intends to do: take the Liberals from third party status back to power – or at least somewhere close. Maybe he can do that. But maybe he should reconsider his tendency to mouth off in front of journalists.

It went something like this: Trudeau was back in Ottawa after having given a contentious interview with Radio-Canada in Quebec earlier this year in which had wondered aloud whether "if at a certain point, I believe that Canada was really the Canada of [prime minister] Stephen Harper – that we are going against abortion, and we were going against gay marriage and we were going backwards in 10,000 different ways – maybe I would think about wanting to make Quebec a country." Boom. La gaffe. The son of the prime minister whose government instituted the Official Languages Act, stared down a referendum on Quebec sovereignty, and then patriated the constitution without that province, had said what? Did he want Quebec to separate? Didn't he love Canada? What about federalism? Was this outburst as bad as when he'd called a minister a "piece of shit" in the House two months prior? The Ottawa press gallery waited for him after Question Period on Valentine's Day for some answers.

What they got was performance art. Trudeau, in full stride, launched himself out of the House of Commons into the foyer and to the nearest microphone. He was quickly surrounded by reporters. He spoke: "Canadians should not be asking 'Oh, does Justin Trudeau want to separate?' Of course not! But will Justin Trudeau fight with his very last breath to make sure that this Canada stays the Canada that we collectively know it can be? Absolutely." He took no further questions; gave a quick "merci beaucoup.", turned on his heel and walked away. An awkward silence followed. Had he just spoken in the third person?

Probably Team Trudeau would rather forget the episode and also hope to never repeat it, but who knows. Perhaps Trudeau's pontifications will become the centrepiece of his campaign, but probably not, given how silent he's been in the House of Commons recently – even when, so the scuttlebutt goes, his party has offered him the chance. And if not, it seems the question for Trudeau as he enters into the leadership race over a month before it will officially get under way is whether he can convince anyone in Canada he's capable of more than just an entertaining performance. Maybe he's made of more than he's yet shown. Maybe he is as he was in the final rounds of his boxing victory against a Conservative senator. Maybe Justin Trudeau is tougher and swifter than many around here give him credit for. If you listen to Liberals, a number of them are certainly banking on all of it.

But they're also banking on the possibility that it doesn't actually matter whether he is or not. More important than anything is Trudeau's image, and, more specifically, that he already has one and that it is at least already partly formed in everybody's mind from coast to coast, for good or bad. Unlike the last Liberal leader, the international intellectual professor Michael Ignatieff, Trudeau is a known entity. The first thing the Conservatives did to Ignatieff was brand him as some kind of elitist alien troubadour, full of wild political poetry about socialism or something. And he never recovered; the Liberals were reduced to third party status in the 2011 election. Trudeau, for all the blustering and boxing, is already, by and large, someone Canadians know, even if they hate his guts. For the Liberals, this is a good thing.

Chances are Trudeau knows this. And chances are it doesn't bother him. He's also probably counting on the fact that, if placed between Harper and New Democrat leader Thomas Mulcair – both white men in their 50s – he'll look damned good. He probably would. fields.bodyText: There is one recent instance that parliamentary reporters in Ottawa will recount when prompted with a question about how good Justin Trudeau might be at leading the Liberal party, and it's not a good one. Trudeau, who is 40 and the son of the former Canadian prime minister Pierre Trudeau, formally announced his intention to run for the Liberal party leadership on Tuesday evening at a rally in his home Montreal riding. His bid for leadership of the faltering Liberals was the worst-kept secret in Canadian politics, because everyone was eventually in on the whispering, and ran to tell the world about it. But now we know for sure what Trudeau intends to do: take the Liberals from third party status back to power – or at least somewhere close. Maybe he can do that. But maybe he should reconsider his tendency to mouth off in front of journalists. It went something like this: Trudeau was back in Ottawa after having given a contentious interview with Radio-Canada in Quebec earlier this year in which had wondered aloud whether "if at a certain point, I believe that Canada was really the Canada of [prime minister] Stephen Harper – that we are going against abortion, and we were going against gay marriage and we were going backwards in 10,000 different ways – maybe I would think about wanting to make Quebec a country." Boom. La gaffe. The son of the prime minister whose government instituted the Official Languages Act, stared down a referendum on Quebec sovereignty, and then patriated the constitution without that province, had said what? Did he want Quebec to separate? Didn't he love Canada? What about federalism? Was this outburst as bad as when he'd called a minister a "piece of shit" in the House two months prior? The Ottawa press gallery waited for him after Question Period on Valentine's Day for some answers. What they got was performance art. Trudeau, in full stride, launched himself out of the House of Commons into the foyer and to the nearest microphone. He was quickly surrounded by reporters. He spoke: "Canadians should not be asking 'Oh, does Justin Trudeau want to separate?' Of course not! But will Justin Trudeau fight with his very last breath to make sure that this Canada stays the Canada that we collectively know it can be? Absolutely." He took no further questions; gave a quick "merci beaucoup.", turned on his heel and walked away. An awkward silence followed. Had he just spoken in the third person? Probably Team Trudeau would rather forget the episode and also hope to never repeat it, but who knows. Perhaps Trudeau's pontifications will become the centrepiece of his campaign, but probably not, given how silent he's been in the House of Commons recently – even when, so the scuttlebutt goes, his party has offered him the chance. And if not, it seems the question for Trudeau as he enters into the leadership race over a month before it will officially get under way is whether he can convince anyone in Canada he's capable of more than just an entertaining performance. Maybe he's made of more than he's yet shown. Maybe he is as he was in the final rounds of his boxing victory against a Conservative senator. Maybe Justin Trudeau is tougher and swifter than many around here give him credit for. If you listen to Liberals, a number of them are certainly banking on all of it. But they're also banking on the possibility that it doesn't actually matter whether he is or not. More important than anything is Trudeau's image, and, more specifically, that he already has one and that it is at least already partly formed in everybody's mind from coast to coast, for good or bad. Unlike the last Liberal leader, the international intellectual professor Michael Ignatieff, Trudeau is a known entity. The first thing the Conservatives did to Ignatieff was brand him as some kind of elitist alien troubadour, full of wild political poetry about socialism or something. fields.headline: Canada's political punch-up
fields.standfirst: What happens when you put a Liberal MP and a Conservative senator in a boxing ring to fight it out? Not what you'd expect
fields.trailText: Colin Horgan: What happens when you put a Liberal MP and a Conservative senator in a boxing ring to fight it out? Not what you'd expect
fields.body:
It might be commonplace to graft extensive sports analogies on to discussions about politics, but Saturday night in Ottawa offered a particularly special occasion. Here is what happened, in brief: two politicians stepped into a boxing ring set up in a large conference room of a hotel complex in the city's suburbs and physically beat each other for a few minutes. It was the metaphorical becoming literal. And, probably predictably, it was borderline surreal.

There are two ways to explain the fight. The simplest explanation is that it was an effort to raise money for cancer research, which it did – some $230,000 (£144,000). More complicated, however, is articulating all of the elements of a narrative built up not just since Liberal MP Justin Trudeau and Conservative senator Patrick Brazeau decided to face one another in the ring, but over years of Liberal and Conservative political battles, ones that have in the past decade fallen heavily to the Conservatives in almost every way.

With that in mind, the combatants probably could not have been better picked. Trudeau, 40, is the son of former prime minister Pierre Trudeau, the name held up to by those on the right as the man responsible for leading Canada into socialist backwaters until a sensible, cold-hearted Conservative came in to lower taxes, brutalise criminals, and rule like a king. On the other side was Brazeau, 37, a trash-talking, ex-military karate black belt and former aboriginal chief, appointed to the senate in 2009 – a perfect embodiment of a particularly brash, fuck-you strain of the current Conservative rhetoric.

Then into the mix came Sun TV News, a sort of northern answer to Fox News. Sun TV bought the exclusive broadcast rights to the fight, and featured an endless pre-show in which its hosts promoted the rebranding of Earth Hour as Human Achievement Hour, a time when people are encouraged to keep lights on.

The network appeared almost gleeful with anticipation of the fight, and the prospect of watching Trudeau – or "Shiny Pony", a reference to the flowing hair he would have to cut should he lose – go down hard. And because it was widely assumed Trudeau would be beaten, perhaps badly, by Brazeau (the latter was given three to one odds), the nation awaited the picture and caption the rightwing tabloids would carry on Sunday morning. A Liberal defeated. Again. A nation surely altered. Again, this time for good. End scene on the Grit century.

As expected, the crowd in the windowless, concrete convention hall-turned-gala venue on Saturday seemed heavily weighted in favour of Brazeau before the fight began, with chants of his name ringing louder than those for Trudeau. But after the fight's first round, the anticipated script veered wildly off course. Trudeau appeared to adopt a kind of Homer Simpson style of fighting – he allowed Brazeau to hit him early and quickly, waited for his energy to run dry, and then retaliated. It worked. Trudeau gained the upper hand early in the second round, and as the tilt wore on, the result started to become clearer.

Trudeau won.

Not only did he win, he did it via a technical knockout, leaving Brazeau battered and exhausted against the ropes. In the end, the fight didn't even go three full rounds. By the time it was over, the "Papineau Pugilist", the elite centrist moderate from Montreal, handed the Conservative an unexpected, crushing loss, and his own party supporters a moment of pure catharsis.

What does this all mean for Canadian politics, if anything? Likely, it will simply be a nice memory for the Liberals in the future, during what looks set to be years of rebuilding for the party – finally a point of pride in a line of undignified defeats.

Some, however, have already speculated the victory will be a launching point for a Trudeau bid at Liberal party leadership. That would be odd. But so was Saturday.

fields.headline: Michael Ignatieff resigns after Canada poll defeat for Liberal party
fields.standfirst: Liberals came in a distant third in Monday's elections with just 34 seats giving Stephen Harper's Conservatives a majority
fields.trailText: Liberals came in a distant third in Monday's elections with just 34 seats giving Stephen Harper's Conservatives a majority
fields.body:
Michael Ignatieff, the man once hailed as the "bionic liberal", has stepped down as Canada's Liberal leader after leading the party to its worst ever election defeat.

The Liberals came in a distant third in Monday night's elections with 34 seats, giving Stephen Harper's Conservatives, on 167 seats, a majority in the 308-seat House of Commons.

The collapse of the Liberals, the traditional party of governance for the 20th century, has redrawn the map of Canadian politics. The leftwing New Democratic party, led by Jack Layton, nearly tripled their strength to 102 seats, emerging for the first time as the official opposition.

Voters also elected the first Green party MP, Elizabeth May, in British Columbia, and threw out all but four members of the French-speaking separatist Bloc Québécois.

Ignatieff's humiliation was compounded by the loss of his own seat. On Tuesday morning, the exhausted-looking leader blamed the Liberals' collapse on negative attack ads. Canadians liked him once they got to know him, he told a press conference, but "there were these negative attack ads that made it very difficult for me to connect with people who weren't in the room," he said. "I had a very large square put around my neck for a number of years."

But Ignatieff, who became a public figure in the 1990s as the telegenic host of BBC's Late Show before decamping for a job at Harvard as a human rights professor, said he took responsibility for the defeat. "The only thing Canadians like less than a loser is a sore loser and I go out of politics with my head held high," he said.

The party will meet next week to choose an interim leader. Ignatieff said he wanted to return to academia, the career he gave up in 2005 to make his first run for office in a suburban Toronto district, though he said he had had no offers as yet.

Ignatieff, who was cast by some party grandees as the great hope for an ailing party in search of a charismatic leader, became leader in 2009. But under his leadership, the Liberals were reduced to less than 19% of the popular vote and Harper got his first majority after five years of minority rule.

Commentators said Harper now had an historic opportunity to move the centre of Canadian politics further to the right.

In the immediate future, the Conservative majority gives Harper a chance to push through an economic agenda of corporate tax breaks and government spending cuts.

At a press conference in Calgary on Tuesday, he said the result would bring stability to Canada, which has seen four elections in seven years. He also offered reassurances about an immediate lurch to the right because of pressure from his party's right wing.

"We are intensely aware that we are and we must be the government of all Canadians, including those who did not vote for us," Harper said.

Layton, whose party won more than 30% of the popular vote, must now fashion a credible opposition force from a large and inexperienced group.

The party's biggest wins came from Quebec, where it became the default choice for voters fed up with the Bloc Québécois.

One of the winners from Quebec on Monday night, Ruth Ellen Brosseau, works in a bar in Ottawa, does not speak French, and may not have ever visited her district, Canadian press reported. She also spent part of the campaign on holiday in Las Vegas - but she still took 40% of the vote.

Other prominent casualties include the leader of the Bloc Québécois, Gilles Duceppe, who stood down after his party lost nearly all of its members.

The Liberal party collapse claimed other high-profile figures. In Toronto, Ken Dryden, a goalie in the National Hockey League before entering law and politics, lost to a conservative. However, Justin Trudeau, the son of the late prime minister Pierre Trudeau, held on to his seat in Quebec.

fields.headline: Cold comfort
fields.standfirst: Skiers lured by British Columbia's pristine wilderness have had a stark reminder of the risks involved, after two deadly avalanches in less than a fortnight, writes Anne McIlroy
fields.trailText: Skiers lured by British Columbia's pristine wilderness have had a stark reminder of the risks involved, after two deadly avalanches in less than a fortnight, writes Anne McIlroy
fields.body:
More and more Canadians are venturing into the remote backcountry during winter, strapping skins on their skis to get as far as possible from the hordes that crowd commercial ski centres. Last week came another chilling reminder of how dangerous mountain wilderness can be.

Seven teenagers on a backcountry ski trip, organised by their school in Calgary, were killed when an avalanche swept down the mountain they were traversing near Revelstoke, British Columbia. It was the second avalanche tragedy in less than two weeks. On January 20, another avalanche in the same area killed seven, including Craig Kelly, a former world-champion snowboarder and pioneer in his sport.

But it was the death of seven youngsters, killed the same day the space shuttle Columbia blew up over Texas, that has prompted serious questions, both about avalanche safety in Canada, and the wisdom of taking children on these kinds of trips. "What kind of character are we trying to build by this type of adventure? Rambos? Conquerors?," the grandfather of one of the victims asked at the first of seven funerals.

The trip to one of the most dangerous avalanche areas in the world was part of an outdoor education programme designed to foster leadership skills. The school is an elite private institution - which in Canada means parents must pay in order for their children to attend, although there are scholarships available. Fearing lawsuits, school officials have refused to comment, but have launched an internal investigation.

The risk of avalanche was rated "considerable" on the day the 17-member Calgary school expedition set out. Two wilderness guides on the same trail saw the avalanche roaring down on the school group, and yelled a warning, but there was no time for the kids and their three teachers to get out of the way. The guides managed to dig out the 10 survivors, but the victims were buried under metres of deep and heavy snow, and suffocated before they could be reached.

The rating of "considerable" is common - the mid-point of 5-point danger scale - and if skiers waited for the experts to say the risk of an avalanche was low, they would never get out into the mountains, says safety researcher David McClung.

His avalanche safety research was axed by the federal government in 1991, and since then he has had to scramble to find private companies to fund his work. Only in Russia is the situation as dire for scientists who study avalanches, he said. In Europe, they have strong government support.

There are daily avalanche bulletins in most parts of Europe, while the Canadian Avalanche Association only puts out its warnings three times a week. The ratings have to cover areas as large as Switzerland because the CAA doesn't have the money to do more in-depth assessments.

Still, all the research money in the world may not have helped save the seven children. Most avalanche victims are killed in slides they trigger themselves. In this case, it appears the skiers were terribly unlucky. They were in the wrong place as a massive avalanche swept down from higher up on the mountain.

But that doesn't mean government cutbacks aren't putting lives at risk. Justin Trudeau, the son of former prime minister Pierre Trudeau, became an avalanche safety campaigner a few years ago after his younger brother Michel was swept to his death by an avalanche.

Trudeau has been demanding more public funding. Last week, the British Columbia government responded, and a daily bulletin assessing the risk throughout mountain skiing areas in Alberta and British Columbia will now be produced. That is good news for the skiers who come from across Canada and around the world seeking pristine wilderness. They should be able to better assess the dangers of venturing into the mountains, an experience they say is well worth the risk of dying in an avalanche.
